What is a shortcode? It’s basically a block-level html code; you can write shortcodes yourself and find ones online that others have written for you. You have two sets of curly braces and a set of angle brackets { { < short code > } } at the beginning of the shortcode and { { < /short code > } } at the end of the shortcode. (For some reason the website won’t compile if I actually type it out correctly, which is without the spaces between each symbols.)
How can I find “built-in” shortcodes? Under the themes/layouts/shorcodes folder, you can find the ones that come with your theme. For example, here are some that come with the PaperMod theme:
Collapse here’s the shortcode for collapse inside the collapse you can have a lot of things inside but you can’t have Markdown Syntax inside of shortcode :< Figure here’s the shortcode for collapse inside the collapse you can have a lot of things inside but you can’t have Markdown Syntax inside of shortcode :< Let’s take YouTube videos as an example Sources HUGO Shortcodes Mike Dane’s YouTube video

content:
Why building a website with Hugo? In short, it’s a really fast and simple way to have a static website to yourself, through which you can display your recent projects, share your thoughts, and have fun with it.
Before we officially start… The tutorial is based on macOS and I’m using GitHub Pages for deployment.
Tools you’ll need Terminal A text editor like VSCode A GitHub account hugo Setting up Open your terminal - easy! ‚≠êÔ∏è tip: command + space and search terminal in your Spotlight
Install hugo brew install hugo To check that hugo is properly installed,
hugo version Your terminal should look something like
hugo v0.101.0+extended darwin/arm64 BuildDate=unknown Install git git --version If you already have git installed, it will look something like
git version 2.35.0 If not, the command will automatically prompt installation.
Now… How do we actually make the website? Build it locally first Locate a place for your website You may want to cd into a specific directory for your new website, but we can also just start by putting it on our Desktop.
cd Desktop hugo new site yourPreferredFolderName I will use personalWebsite for my folder.
It’s time to publish it! There are many ways to deploy
Sources Hugo: Quick Start Medium: Build a Personal Website With Github Pages and Hugo Git: Installing Git
